results.title: Co-Administration of Pioglitazone Improves Fluoxetine's Antinociceptive, Neuroprotective, and Antidepressant Effects in Chronic Constriction Injury in Rats.
results.text_hl: OBJECTIVE: This study was designed to investigate the potential antinociceptive, neuroprotective, and antidepressant effects of combinations of @CHEMICAL_Pioglitazone @CHEMICAL_MESH:D000077205 @@@pioglitazone@@@ or @<m>CHEMICAL_Metformin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D008687 @@@metformin@@@ with @CHEMICAL_Fluoxetine @CHEMICAL_MESH:D005473 @@@fluoxetine@@@ in @<m>DISEASE_Brain_Injury_Chronic</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D020208 @@@chronic constriction injury@@@ (@<m>DISEASE_Brain_Injury_Chronic</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D020208 @@@CCI@@@) in @SPECIES_10116 @@@rats@@@.

citations.NLM: Murad H, Ayuob N. Co-Administration of Pioglitazone Improves Fluoxetine's Antinociceptive, Neuroprotective, and Antidepressant Effects in Chronic Constriction Injury in Rats. Pain Physician. 2015 Nov;18(6):609-20. PMID: 26606013
citations.BibTeX: @article{26606013, title={Co-Administration of Pioglitazone Improves Fluoxetine's Antinociceptive, Neuroprotective, and Antidepressant Effects in Chronic Constriction Injury in Rats.}, author={Murad H and Ayuob N}, journal={Pain Physician}, volume={18}, number={6}, pages={609-20}}

results.title: Metformin antinociceptive effect in models of nociceptive and neuropathic pain is partially mediated by activation of opioidergic mechanisms.
results.text_hl: Single and repeated administration of @<m>CHEMICAL_Metformin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D008687 @@@metformin@@@ (250, 500 or 1000 mg/kg) inhibited the @DISEASE_Hyperalgesia @DISEASE_MESH:D006930 @@@mechanical allodynia@@@ induced by @<m>DISEASE_Brain_Injury_Chronic</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D020208 @@@CCI@@@.

citations.NLM: Augusto PSA, Braga AV, Rodrigues FF, Morais MI, Dutra MMGB, Batista CRA, Melo ISF, Costa SOAM, Goulart FA, Coelho MM, Machado RR. Metformin antinociceptive effect in models of nociceptive and neuropathic pain is partially mediated by activation of opioidergic mechanisms. Eur J Pharmacol. 2019 Sep 5;858():172497. PMID: 31238066
